title: Level 9 Statistics Practice Test
description: Test your understanding of bivariate data, box plots, quartiles, and probability with and without replacement.

questions.question: Which prediction type is generally more reliable — interpolation or extrapolation?
questions.explanation: Interpolation (predicting within the data range) is more reliable than extrapolation (predicting outside the data range), because we have evidence that the trend holds within the data range.

questions.question: The five-number summary of a data set is: Min = 10, Q1 = 20, Median = 35, Q3 = 50, Max = 70. What is the IQR?
questions.explanation: IQR $= Q3 - Q1 = 50 - 20 = 30$. The IQR measures the spread of the middle 50% of the data.

questions.question: A bag has 6 red and 4 blue marbles. One marble is drawn and replaced, then another is drawn. What is $P(\text{both red})$?
A bag has 6 red and 4 blue marbles. One marble is drawn and NOT replaced, then another is drawn. What is $P(\text{both red})$?
questions.explanation: Without replacement: $P(RR) = \frac{6}{10} \times \frac{5}{9} = \frac{30}{90} = \frac{1}{3}$. After removing one red, there are 5 red left out of 9 total.

questions.question: In a box plot, the box represents which portion of the data?
questions.explanation: The box extends from Q1 to Q3, covering the middle 50% of the data (the interquartile range).

questions.question: A spinner has $P(\text{Red}) = 0.3$ and $P(\text{Blue}) = 0.7$. It is spun twice. What is $P(\text{at least one red})$?
questions.explanation: $P(\text{at least one red}) = 1 - P(\text{no reds}) = 1 - P(BB) = 1 - 0.7 \times 0.7 = 1 - 0.49 = 0.51$.

questions.question: Find the IQR for the data: $4, 8, 10, 12, 15, 18, 20, 24$. (Hint: Q1 is the median of the lower half.)
A bag has 5 red and 3 blue marbles. Two are drawn without replacement. What is $P(\text{both blue})$? Give your answer as a simplified fraction.
The equation of a line of best fit is $y = 3x + 10$. Predict the $y$-value when $x = 8$.
A coin is flipped 3 times. Using the formula for independent events, what is the probability of getting 3 heads? Give your answer as a fraction.
